utterances: Diphtheria?
Diphtheria for - I don't know why that was the jackpot disease.
But it seems like that was.
But anyway, that they were told they needed to do that.
And these two mass gatherings have decided to send these folks to were the NASCAR racers in Talladega, Alabama, and here at Charlotte, North Carolina.
And of courseâ€¦
I gather the fans were not too happy at the association.
Well, yeah.

The idea that you do to get the kind of vaccinations you would get to go to a Third World country and maybe they'll go out and do a safari or something were not necessarily what they thought you should have to get to come to Alabama.
You know, Alabama's tourism slogan and North Carolina's tourism slogan is not come to North Carolina but make sure you get your shots first.
And so now, you're there at the Lowes Motor Speedway outside Charlotte.
Are people walking around in their hazmat suits?
There will be a fly over here later tonight by military jets, unless they, you know, decide to do it by crop-dusting the crowd.
I don't think there'll be any kind of mass health action taking place here tonight, no, ma'am.
Are you hearing from fans that they've heard about this?
Have fans heard about it much?
Yeah, you know.
And I think that this was one of those stories that if you'd just generally think the government is a bunch of idiots, this sort of confirms your suspicions.
I think that the fans think that these people kind of look down their nose at NASCAR fans and this is another example of that.
And, you know, there's some political footballing going back and forth, that's kind of sort of spin at their way or spin it against the other side.
And, you know, I was doing a radio show Friday morning on Sirius Satellite Radio and we were talking to both congressmen who were involved in the sort of this.
The chairman of the committee, a Democrat of Mississippi named Benny Thompson, basically says, well, we're just trying to do what we're supposed to do.
We're sending people out into the field and, you know, if there was an outbreak, we want our people prepared.
While on the other hand, Robin Hayes, who is the Republican congressman who represents the district in where this track sits, took offense, you know.
He's almost like why do you have to have shots to go to my hometown?
David Poole covers motor sports for the Charlotte Observer.
And he's the co-host of the ""Morning Drive"" on Sirius NASCAR Radio.
Thanks so much for joining us.
My pleasure.
From NPR News, this is All Things Considered.
I'm Michele Norris.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
Karl Rove, President Bush's closest political adviser, is stepping down at the end of the month.
He's the architect of the president's White House campaigns and Republican Party strategy.
Officially, he is Deputy Chief of Staff.
Rove also is the latest in a line of White House officials heading for the exits as the Bush Administration winds down.
Karl Rove leaves behind a mixed legacy, many political wins, but some major miscalculations, too.
We have two reports, first NPR's Brian Naylor.
The announcement this morning on the South Lawn of the White House was an emotional moment for the two men who have had such a symbiotic relationship over the years.
President Bush sounded a bit wistful as he mentioned, not the advice Rove gave him, but the friendship he provided.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: We've known each other as youngsters interested in serving our state.
And we worked together so we can be in a position to serve this country.
And so I thank my friend.
I'll be on the road behind you here in a little bit.
Rove, his voice quavering, said the years he spent Mr. Bush were an exhilarating and eventful time.
The school day should have begun here at least an hour ago.
So far only 20 girls have turned up.
The rest, some 480 of them, are staying away.
And I'm grateful to have been witness to history.
It has been a joy and the honor of a lifetime.
I've seen a man of far-sighted courage put America on a war footing and protect us against a brutal enemy in a dangerous conflict that will shape this new century.
The two men briefly hugged and then walked to the Marine helicopter that would take them on the first part of their journey together back to Texas.
Karl Rove leaves behind a reputation in Washington that is equal parts political mastermind and bareknuckle brawler.
He was instrumental in Mr. Bush's political career directing his campaigns for governor and then for the White House.

In 2002, he oversaw a midterm election campaign in which Republicans increased their numbers in Congress, the first time the president's party had accomplished that in a first term midterm election since 1934.

Two years later, Republicans again added to their congressional majority as President Bush was returned to the White House, thanks in part to a GOP Get-Out-the-Vote campaign that turned out Bush voters in record numbers.

While the vaunted 72-hour plan Rove helped design identified likely Bush voters, Rove was also instrumental in honing the message, which in the wake of the 9/11 attacks and the Iraq war demonized Democrats.
Here he is speaking about the 2006 campaign.
President Bush believes if al-Qaida is calling somebody in America, it is in our national security interest to know who they're calling and why.
Some of important Democrats clearly disagree.
The politicization of national security was a hallmark of Rove's tenure as chief political operative.

In an interview with the Wall Street Journal today, Rove said the Democrats were likely to nominate Hillary Rodham Clinton as their presidential nominee next year and he labeled her, quote, ""tough, tenacious and fatally flawed."" But Rove's predictions have hardly been flawless.
He told this show last fall that Republicans would retain control of Congress despite a wealth of public poll showing the opposite.
I'm looking at all of these, Robert, and add them up, and I add up to a Republican Senate or a Republican House.
You may end up with a different math but you're entitled to your math.
I'm entitled to the math.
Rove's math, however, added up wrong, and the Democratic Congress he insisted was out of the question is now hot in his pursuit.
Several committees in the House and Senate are interested in questioning Rove about everything from this involvement in the leaking of Valerie Plame's name to the firings of U.S.
attorneys and the disappearance of thousands of e-mails.
Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Vermont Democrat Patrick Leahy.
I am surprised that he is leaving before the end of the term, but I'm not sure of what does he intend to do.
He has not answered our subpoenas in the Judiciary Committee.
He's still going to be subject to the subpoenas.
We will continue to push forward.
For his part, Rove told the Wall Street Journal his future plans include time with his family and to write a book on the Bush years.
He says he's unlikely to take any formal role in the 2008 campaigns.
Brian Naylor, NPR News, the White House.
In neighboring Belarus this weekend, riot police arrested and beat demonstrators protesting last week's presidential vote there, which returned strong man Alexander Lukashenko to power.
The U.S.
and the European Union have responded to the rigged vote by expanding the list of Belarussians who will be denied visas to the West.
President Lukashenko is now on that list.
NPR's Michelle Kelemen reports on how sanctions might or might not work.
President Lukashenko can forget about European ski trips and his aides may have to forgo their shopping sprees.
That's the message the U.S.
and the European Union are sending, according to David Cortright, co-author of the book, The Sanctions Decade.
It seems that they're less able to access their financial resources.
They may not be able to travel to Paris or London to go shopping.

I mean these are very small measures, but they are a form of irritant and they send a signal, politically, that the European Union, the U.S., other Western governments are not willing to accept repressive measures and undemocratic procedures.
They also said a signal he says to democracy activists that the West has not forgotten them.
The U.S.
and the European Union rejected the outcome of last Sunday's vote and condemned Belarus authorities for rounding up hundreds of demonstrators.
The election was just the latest in a long list of complaints that the West has about Lukashenko, often dubbed the Last Dictator in Europe.
Both the U.S.
and the European Union have had some targeted sanctions in place for the past few years.
But a European commission spokeswoman, Emma Udwin(ph), says for the first time President Lukashenko himself will be denied visas along with other top officials.
There can sometimes be some exceptions to that if there is to be some meeting held that would allow us to raise important points about the need to promote democracy and human rights.
It does not allow for exceptions that will allow tourism, shopping.
And she says Belarus officials could have their assets frozen.
Now, that is a measure that can have a significant psychological effect.
It's quite hard to implement.
We've been warning the Belarussian authorities that we intended to take further restrictive measures if these elections were not free and fair since last November.
So my guess is that anyone who had money in Europe has had plenty of time to think about putting it somewhere else.

The idea behind these targeted sanctions is to try to get some of Lukashenko's supporters in the government to split with the hardline Belarus leader, but Michael McFall, a professor at Stanford University and an expert on the region, sees little signs of a split at this point and he says while targeted sanctions can be effective at times, he's skeptical they'll will make much of a difference in this case.
I think it's rather optimistic to believe that this would then cause these particular individuals to defect from Mr. Lukashenko.
This is an authoritarian regime.
This is not a regime that has a bunch of oligarchs, billionaires who have assets abroad.
These are people who have money only because of their ties to the state.
So we're having to resort back to electronics and doing the best we can.
Begum says she's asked her handful of staff - all of them are women -to help her keep the school going no matter how few students they have.
Almost 100 girls' schools in Swat Valley have been firebombed by the Taliban in little more than a year.
Hotelier Ibrahim Mohammed(ph) says the local people don't know what to do.
They are powerless.
What do they do?
They are only condemning.
You know that in Islam, what Islam told us?
Acquiring knowledge is incumbent upon every Muslim man and woman.
So how we should against it that the women should not get education or for tomorrow we will bomb their schools?
Ibrahim has daughters.
The day before yesterday, I heard that their day school was burned, somebody burned their school.
Fortunately they were not (unintelligible) at that time in their school.
That must be very worrying for you though.
